Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Gastrointestinal Injuries Post-Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they underwent CPB. This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a cardiac surgery setting.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a specific treatment targeting gastrointestinal injuries, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates interventions for gastrointestinal injuries post-CPB.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of gastrointestinal injuries within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in gastrointestinal injuries (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.
